Metz http://mason.gmu.edu/~smetz3 עַם יִשְׂרָאֵל חַי נֵ֣צַח יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לֹ֥א יְשַׁקֵּ֖ר ________________________________________ From: IBM Mainframe Discussion List <IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU> on behalf of Richard Zierdt <Richard.Zierdt@FRESCHESOLUTIONS.COM> Sent: Monday, March 17, 2025 2:32 PM To: IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU Subject: AR Mode: MVCL R0,Rx No; MVCL Rx,Ry Yes External Message: Use Caution The following is documented in PoPs, but what the hey. Primary (ASC) Mode: MVCL R0,Rx is fine AR (ASC) Mode: MVCL R0,Rx is *not* fine — AR0 is not honored [...]

item.author: Martin Packer <martin_packer@UK.IBM.COM>

item.title: Re: AR Mode: MVCL R0,Rx No; MVCL Rx,Ry Yes
item.description:
On Mon, 17 Mar 2025 at 14:32, Richard Zierdt <
Richard.Zierdt@freschesolutions.com> wrote:

> The following is documented in PoPs, but what the hey.
>
> Primary (ASC) Mode: MVCL R0,Rx is fine
>
> AR (ASC) Mode: MVCL R0,Rx is *not* fine — AR0 is not honored
>
> The PoPs manual on MVCL:
>
> "In the access-register mode, the contents of access
> register R1 and access register R2 are compared. If
> the R1 or R2 field is zero, 32 zeros are used rather
> than the contents of access register 0. "
> [...]
item.author: Tony Harminc <tony@HARMINC.NET>

item.title: Re: AR Mode: MVCL R0,Rx No; MVCL Rx,Ry Yes
item.description:
I'm confused: it seems clear to me: AR0 is ignored same as GPR0 when specified? What am I missing...

-----Original Message-----
From: IBM Mainframe Discussion List <IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU> On Behalf Of Binyamin Dissen
Sent: Monday, March 17, 2025 3:25 PM
To: IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU
Subject: Re: AR Mode: MVCL R0,Rx No; MVCL Rx,Ry Yes

I see it as the opposite. [...]
item.author: Phil Smith III <lists@AKPHS.COM>

item.title: Re: AR Mode: MVCL R0,Rx No; MVCL Rx,Ry Yes
item.description:
I see it as the opposite.

I would not have expected R0 to address data.

But in the case of MVCL R0 is explicitly specified, (unlike other instructions
where 0 is the absence of a base/index register) so that may be why they
allowed it to address data. Perhaps the hardware cannot use AR0 in that way. [...]
item.author: Binyamin Dissen <bdissen@DISSENSOFTWARE.COM>

item.title: AR Mode: MVCL R0,Rx No; MVCL Rx,Ry Yes
item.description:
The following is documented in PoPs, but what the hey.

Primary (ASC) Mode: MVCL R0,Rx is fine

AR (ASC) Mode: MVCL R0,Rx is *not* fine — AR0 is not honored

The PoPs manual on MVCL:

"In the access-register mode, the contents of access
register R1 and access register R2 are compared. If
the R1 or R2 field is zero, 32 zeros are used rather
than the contents of access register 0. " [...]
item.author: Richard Zierdt <Richard.Zierdt@FRESCHESOLUTIONS.COM>

item.title: Re: Links for ESS manuals
item.description: The problem is that we are not the customer, we are the product. Google is in the business of selling eyeballs. Nor is google the only offender. I keep seeing ads from Temu for Butyl Mercaptan; the links go to totally unrelated products. Presumably if I search for foo then I want to buy foo! -- Shmuel (Seymour J.) Metz http://mason.gmu.edu/~smetz3 עַם יִשְׂרָאֵל חַי נֵ֣צַח יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לֹ֥א יְשַׁקֵּ֖ר ________________________________________ From: IBM Mainframe Discussion List <IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU> on behalf of billogden <billogden@OPTONLINE.NET> Sent: Monday, March 17, 2025 10:39 AM To: IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU Subject: Re: Links for ESS manuals External Message: Use Caution > [...]
item.author: Seymour J Metz <smetz3@GMU.EDU>

item.title: Re: Links for ESS manuals
item.description:
My problem isn't that google gives me a URL for an older version, it's that google doesn't give me a URL for any version but does give me URLs that have nothing to do with what I'm searching for.

For z/OS and z/VM, the URLs seem to be stable, and I can navigate from a release-specific page to the main page. But what I'm looking for are hardware manuals that I couldn't find on bitsavers.
item.author: Seymour J Metz <smetz3@GMU.EDU>

item.title: Re: Links for ESS manuals
item.description:
That would require either (a) manual updates when versions change or (b) a real CMS (not VM CMS). Remember, IBM moved all their web stuff to other countries and nobody understands it any more.

item.title: Re: Links for ESS manuals
item.description:
IBM should remove the version number from the URL's for the latest doc.
Then maybe Google will get the hint and quit sending me to old versions,
unless I'm specifically looking for those.

https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/zos/ < current
https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/zos/2.5.0 < old
https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/zos/2.4.0 < older

Then when the new version arrives:

https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/zos/ < current
https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/zos/3.1.0 < old
https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/zos/2.5.0 < older
https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/zos/2.4.0 < older [...]
item.author: Tom Brennan <tom@TOMBRENNANSOFTWARE.COM>

item.title: Re: Links for ESS manuals
item.description:
> I have found google to be useless for locating old IBM manuals.

While it is not exactly relevant to IBM-MAIN topics, I seem to see recent
google results as having considerably less "accuracy" than in earlier days
and considerably more "advertising" or "marketing" orientation. I find I am
using it less now than I did a year or two ago. (Even for z/OS-related
searches!) I realize this is a fuzzy topic that could be debated at least a
dozen different ways but, to me at least, it has somewhat reduced the
usefulness of the web. [...]

item.author: David Crayford <dcrayford@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: IBM Abandoning Metal C?
item.description:
On another thread, David Crayford wrote:

>Our understanding is that Metal/C will not be updated for the next
>architecture or the one after that.

Really? Does anyone have any idea why?

Metal C already does not support Z16 architecture. What would it take
to get them to reverse direction?

Dave Cole, Developer

dbcole@gmail.com (personal)
dbcole@colesoft.com (business)
540-456-6518 (cell)
item.author: David Cole <dbcole@COLESOFT.COM>

item.title: Re: New to Z - History of SPF / ISPF Presentation / Tips & Tricks?
item.description:
Hi Steve,

If you are a SHARE member or delegate, login to share.org and search the proceedings archives for any of the many presentations given by the likes of Tom Conley, Dan Dirkse, Bruce Koss, Lionel Dyck, as well as several IBMers. Dan, Lionel and others are also active in LinkedIn groups such as Mainframe Experts, where much information is available too, including history, tips, and tricks. There is also a System Z Enthusiasts Discord community where ISPF is one of many topics of interest. [...]
item.author: Art Gutowski <Arthur.Gutowski@HUNTINGTON.COM>

With what the blazes do they propose to replace it? Or haven't they thought that far ahead?

Sheesh! I knew Armonk politics was nutty as a fruitcake, but this really tops the list. [...]

Rob,

I'd be happy to review the documentation for the new function in the

Colin

item.author: Colin Paice <colinpaice3@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
> On 17 Mar 2025, at 1:14 am, Farley, Peter <0000031df298a9da-dmarc-request@LISTSERV.UA.EDU> wrote:
>
> I too am concerned about Metal/C not keeping up with the hardware generations, especially as it seems that IBM is about to announce another generation.

IBM Data Virtualization Manager is possibly the largest Metal/C application in the world, with millions of lines of code. It is built for every supported architecture, determined at runtime, and dynamically loaded. However, this does not work for z16. [...]
item.author: David Crayford <dcrayford@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
Apologies, I fat fingered the previous email on my iPad.

All our tests have been conducted from a z/OS UNIX shell, which has a maximum region size. Using precompiled headers won’t make much difference since most of the header files being read are part of the runtime and are not precompiled. The XLC compiler used to include precompiled header files, but IBM dropped them, stating they intended to improve compiler performance, making them unnecessary. [...]
item.author: David Crayford <dcrayford@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
T sting region size is pointless. All our tests have been conducted in the shell which has a maximum regi

>
> ﻿Both tests specified REGION=0M. Here are the stats from the two compiles:
>
> Open:
> CPU: 0 HR 00 MIN 01.29 SEC SRB: 0 HR 00 MIN 00.03 SEC
> VIRT: 20K SYS: 244K EXT: 243432K SYS: 25660K
> ATB- REAL: 68856K SLOTS: 0K
> VIRT- ALLOC: 88M SHRD: 0M
>
> Legacy:
> CPU: 0 HR 00 MIN 00.36 SEC SRB: 0 HR 00 MIN [...]
item.author: David Crayford <dcrayford@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
Both tests specified REGION=0M. Here are the stats from the two compiles:

Open:
CPU: 0 HR 00 MIN 01.29 SEC SRB: 0 HR 00 MIN 00.03 SEC
VIRT: 20K SYS: 244K EXT: 243432K SYS: 25660K
ATB- REAL: 68856K SLOTS: 0K
VIRT- ALLOC: 88M SHRD: 0M

Legacy:
CPU: 0 HR 00 MIN 00.36 SEC SRB: 0 HR 00 MIN 00.00 SEC
VIRT: 80K SYS: 252K EXT: 108328K SYS: 16728K
ATB- REAL: 232K SLOTS: 0K
VIRT- ALLOC: 13M SHRD: 0M [...]
item.author: Charles Mills <charlesm@MCN.ORG>

item.title: Re: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
Trying to hold down the noise by doing one reply for all of your great suggestions.

@Peter, no, did not know about .pch. The documentation is sorely lacking. Would like to give that a try but no idea how.
> Did you run both of those tests using the same REGION value on the same LPAR?
Same exact virtual machine on both but I am not certain about the REGION size. Suspect it was the same. I will look when I get back online and possibly re-test. [...]
item.author: Charles Mills <charlesm@MCN.ORG>

item.title: Re: MapMVS
item.description:
Hi Colin

Understood -however we would need a different character as "?" is used by JDS on SYSOUT panels.

Apropos of nothing, there is a new release of SDSF coming out in September (ahem).

Rob

Sent from Outlook for Android<https://aka.ms/AAb9ysg>

item.author: Seymour J Metz <smetz3@GMU.EDU>

item.title: Re: MapMVS
item.description:
Hi Rob,

One improvement for SDSF would be to have a ? as a line command, as a
shortcut to display the available line command options.
'/' gives all of the columns, but ? would be good as well.

Just a thought...

Colin

On Fri, 14 Mar 2025 at 10:40, Rob Scott <
00000618c90e6fdf-dmarc-request@listserv.ua.edu> wrote:

> Colin
>
> You can try the "JC" action against an address space in SDSF "DA" and also
> the "LPD" primary command.
>
> JC shows the load modules in the ASID and LPD shows the link pack area
> directory.
>
> [...]
item.author: Colin Paice <colinpaice3@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
I too am concerned about Metal/C not keeping up with the hardware generations, especially as it seems that IBM is about to announce another generation.

Has anyone already submitted an “idea” to update Metal/C hardware support? Or in the alternative, to open-source Metal/C so that the community can upgrade it themselves? (Yeah, I know – two chances of that happening: slim and none, but it doesn’t hurt to ask.) [...]
item.author: Farley, Peter <Peter.Farley@BROADRIDGE.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
True about REGION size – the more you give it the faster it will be. Did you run both of those tests using the same REGION value on the same LPAR?

For the new compiler, have the standard library headers all been pre-compiled (suffix “.pch”)? I am told that those make a HUGE difference in C++ compile speeds. [...]
item.author: Farley, Peter <Peter.Farley@BROADRIDGE.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
> On 16 Mar 2025, at 3:02 pm, David Cole <dbcole@COLESOFT.COM> wrote:
>
> I think the more interesting question is not, whether the compiler is slower.
> It's whether the compiled code is slower.
>
> Is it?
>

That’s an interesting question because the legacy XL C/C++ compiler has been functionally stabilized. There is significant concern that Metal/C has not been updated to support the z16 architecture. [...]
item.author: David Crayford <dcrayford@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Executing a clist from debug tool
item.description:
Place

CONTROL LIST SYMLIST CONLIST

in your CLIST.

I think the more interesting question is not, whether the compiler is slower.
It's whether the compiled code is slower.

Is it?

Dave Cole, Developer

item.description:

>>
>>There is a USS (or shell) example given in the same document at https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/open-xl-c-cpp-zos/2.1?topic=applications-compiling which includes both C and C++ compilation parts.
>>
>>Please do ensure your z/OS service level is up to date as well as there may have been changes to the system, compiler, header files, etc.
>>In general, you should NOT need to specify [...]
item.author: Linda Chui <lchui@CA.IBM.COM>

item.title: RACF problem updating RACF BACKUP database (LAST CONNECT date)
item.description:
Hi!

 

I havenoticed a pretty odd situation regarding our RACF backup database that I amstill unable to explain (I have already asked on RACFL).

 

For my own RACFuserid, the LAST-CONNECT date to my “DEFAULT GROUP” is not being updated on theBACKUP RACF database (not even once a day). As far as I have tested, this isonly happening for my own userid (for all the others, things seems to beworking properly). LISTUSER shows the correct LAST-CONNECT date, but, as weknow, RACF commands read information from the PRIMARY RACF database. It is froman IRRDBU00 unload of the RACF BACKUP database [...]
item.author: jgmautalen@yahoo.com.ar <jgmautalen@YAHOO.COM.AR>

item.title: Open XL C dramaticallly slower thant z/OS XL C compiler - expected?
item.description:
I am trying to get started with the new, "open," Clang-based XLC compiler. I am stunned at how noticeably slower it is than the legacy C compiler. I wasn't looking to benchmark -- the slow compile times just jumped out at me.

Is this to be expected? I wish I had numbers for exactly the same source code but there are different userids involved and it's a little complicated. Different options for the two compiles because the option specifications are incompatible. Both modules are fairly vanilla source code written by the same author. [...]
item.author: Charles Mills <charlesm@MCN.ORG>

item.title: Re: New to Z - History of SPF / ISPF Presentation / Tips & Tricks?
item.description: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISPF> has some of the history. -- Shmuel (Seymour J.) Metz http://mason.gmu.edu/~smetz3 עַם יִשְׂרָאֵל חַי נֵ֣צַח יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לֹ֥א יְשַׁקֵּ֖ר ________________________________________ From: IBM Mainframe Discussion List <IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU> on behalf of Steve Estle <000005dcac13570d-dmarc-request@LISTSERV.UA.EDU> Sent: Friday, March 14, 2025 10:55 AM To: IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU Subject: New to Z - History of SPF / ISPF Presentation / Tips & Tricks? External Message: Use Caution Hey Everyone, I'm part of the "New to Z" Community launching in Dallas area and am part of planning committee. We are looking for a good solid presentation that briefly discusses the history of SPF / ISPF/PDF and then goes [...]
item.author: Seymour J Metz <smetz3@GMU.EDU>

item.title: Re: New to Z - History of SPF / ISPF Presentation / Tips & Tricks?
item.description:
Steve,

Below are links to the oldest ISPF/PDF manuals I can find. I remember using
a previous edition of the 'General Information' manual to teach an SPF
class to newbies in the early 1980s. It is a good intro, but the original
audience for that book was TSO line-mode users, folks that were used to the
native TSO line-mode EDIT, SUBMIT, STATUS and TEST commands, etc. [...]
item.author: Mike Shaw <techsupport@QUICKREF.COM>

item.title: New to Z - History of SPF / ISPF Presentation / Tips & Tricks?
item.description:
Hey Everyone,

I'm part of the "New to Z" Community launching in Dallas area and am part of planning committee. We are looking for a good solid presentation that briefly discusses the history of SPF / ISPF/PDF and then goes into some cool / slick things you can do with the product (such as with the ISPF Editor). Just curious what might be out there for New to Z community? [...]

gil
item.author: Paul Gilmartin <PaulGBoulder@AOL.COM>

item.title: Re: MapMVS
item.description:
Rob,

Brilliant! Thank you. It saved me having to schedule an SRB to go and
collect it.

I can now call the loader to map the csects within the loadmodule. I
should be able to do this from rexx!

I'll write this up in a blog post

Colin

On Fri, 14 Mar 2025 at 10:40, Rob Scott <
00000618c90e6fdf-dmarc-request@listserv.ua.edu> wrote: [...]
item.author: Colin Paice <colinpaice3@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Mystified by FTP working for one user but not another
item.description:
On Tue, 11 Mar 2025 18:29:57 -0500 Charles Mills <charlesm@MCN.ORG> wrote:

:>I have a Dallas system where I pretend to be a sysprog. I just added an additional userid. FTP to and from z/OS UNIX files works for my userid but not for the added userid. I have checked and all of the WS_FTP session parameters are the same. I looked at the console and realized I was getting EZB.INITSTACK.*.TCPIP (G) errors every time the new userid tried to transfer a file, so I went aha! and permitted the GROUP to EZB.INITSTACK.*.TCPIP (G) (and yes, did a refresh of SERVAUTH) [...]
item.author: Binyamin Dissen <bdissen@DISSENSOFTWARE.COM>

item.title: Re: Data Spaces in general
item.description:
Right. Duna Williamson, now long retired, did an excellent job with that book. And it has been nicely updated for 64 Bit.

Cheers, Martin

From: IBM Mainframe Discussion List <IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU> on behalf of Rob Scott <00000618c90e6fdf-dmarc-request@LISTSERV.UA.EDU>

To: IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU <IBM-MAIN@LISTSERV.UA.EDU>
Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: Data Spaces in general
I would not advise any new code use dataspaces. Use 64bit memory instead. [...]
item.author: Martin Packer <martin_packer@UK.IBM.COM>

item.title: Re: MapMVS
item.description:
Colin

You can try the "JC" action against an address space in SDSF "DA" and also the "LPD" primary command.

JC shows the load modules in the ASID and LPD shows the link pack area directory.

Rob Scott
Rocket Software
item.author: Rob Scott <rscott@ROCKETSOFTWARE.COM>

item.title: Re: z/PDOS-generic
item.description:
On Wed, 22 Jan 2025 00:53:27 -0600, Paul Edwards <mutazilah@GMAIL.COM> wrote:

>A 35+ year quest to port MSDOS (or similar) to the mainframe
>has now been sufficiently done.
>
>My usual integrity test is to see if gcc 3.2.3 can reproduce itself.
>The z/PDOS-generic version of gcc 3.2.3 can now do this - byte-exact.

>You can get zpg.zip from https://pdos.org and run it under herc32.zip
>or herc64.zip (Hercules/380) from the same place. [...]

item.description:

>Assuming your -mzos-sys-include comes from https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/open-xl-c-cpp-zos/2.1?topic=compiler-jcl-example, you can see the preamble states it is for C (non-XPLINK).
>
>There is a USS (or shell) example given in the same document at https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/open-xl-c-cpp-zos/2.1?topic=applications-compiling which includes both C and C++ compilation parts.
>
>Please do ensure your z/OS service level is up to date as well as there may have been changes to the system, compiler, header files, etc.
>In general, you should NOT need to specify -mzos-sys-include explicitly since the install configuration should have set all the defaults for you. [...]

item.title: Re: Executing a clist from debug tool
item.description:
Peter

My clist has a call command

Let me show you what I am doing

The clist
MYTSOID.CLIST(CALLCMD)’

I type SYS CALLCMD

PROC 0

Call ‘MYTSOID.MYLOADLIB(MYPROG)’

I get the following message ion the the bottom of the debug tool screen

The operating system has generated the following message:

EQA4015I Load module information could not be retrieved for module IKJEFTSR because the loading service ( provider ) that loaded the module loaded it from a system managed library (e.g., LPA). The load module cannot be debugged.
The requested SYSTEM command could not be run
-----Original Message-----
From: IBM Mainframe Discussion List [...]
item.author: Joseph Reichman <reichmanjoe@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C/C++ Documentation
item.description:
On Thu, 13 Mar 2025 08:19:18 -0500, Charles Mills <charlesm@MCN.ORG> wrote:

>On Wed, 12 Mar 2025 19:38:38 -0500, Linda Chui <lchui@CA.IBM.COM> wrote:
>
>>The errors you saw were likely from using the wrong header set.
>
>Linda, thanks for taking the time to help.
>
>I believe I am doing things exactly as you document. The documentation says
>
>-mzos-sys-include="//'<DEFAULT_LE_HLQ, CEE in most cases>.SCEEH.+'"
>
>And my coding is
>
>-mzos-sys-include="//'CEE.SCEEH.+'"
>
>CEE.SCEEH is to the best of my knowledge exactly as installed for the other C compiler V3R1.
>
>Is anyone outside of IBM actually using this compiler?
>
[...]
item.author: Linda Chui <lchui@CA.IBM.COM>

item.title: Re: Open XL C/C++ Documentation
item.description:
On Wed, 12 Mar 2025 19:38:38 -0500, Linda Chui <lchui@CA.IBM.COM> wrote:

>The errors you saw were likely from using the wrong header set.

Linda, thanks for taking the time to help.

I believe I am doing things exactly as you document. The documentation says

-mzos-sys-include="//'<DEFAULT_LE_HLQ, CEE in most cases>.SCEEH.+'"

And my coding is

-mzos-sys-include="//'CEE.SCEEH.+'"

CEE.SCEEH is to the best of my knowledge exactly as installed for the other C compiler V3R1. [...]
item.author: Charles Mills <charlesm@MCN.ORG>

Brian

item.author: Joseph Reichman <reichmanjoe@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Executing a clist from debug tool
item.description:
Hi Joseph,
The z/OS Debugger documentation for the TSO and SYSTEM commands say they
are used to run a "valid TSO system command or CLIST name that *does not
require a parameter*". Trying to pass a parameter might be the cause of
your problem. Please see the first Usage note here for information on how
to overcome this restriction:
https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/debug-for-zos/17.0?topic=commands-system-command-zos [...]
item.author: Peter Van Dyke <pdvandyke@GMAIL.COM>

item.description:

>I think only at the V1.1 (or is it V1.2?) level did the “new” Open XL compiler (the CLANG version) and libraries get support for JCL compilation. The initial version only supported shell invocation.
>

Both versions are installed I believe, but my feeble attempts at testing have been exclusively with V2R1. [...]

item.title: Re: [EXT] Re: Dataspaces
item.description:
Which is a major difference between it and shared 64 bit, where if an address
space gets a share it retains the share even if the creator disposes of the
memory object or terminates.

On Wed, 12 Mar 2025 16:03:27 +0000 Glen Garrison <glene@US.IBM.COM> wrote:

:>Whatever the communication mechanism you choose between creator of, and users of, the scope=common dataspace, the owning task can not terminate before the users are done using it or the users will abend when attempting to access the space. So yes.
:>
:>________________________________
:>From: IBM Mainframe Discussion List on behalf of Ward, Mike S [...]

(This is in the department of old dogs trying to learn new tricks.)

I am very, very familiar with the "legacy" IBM z/OS XL C/C++ compiler. (Is it just me or do these names seem unnecessarily confusing?) [...]
item.author: Charles Mills <charlesm@MCN.ORG>

item.title: Re: Using CSNBRNGL
item.description:
Here's some COBOL which calls CSNBRNGL. I have included calls to STCKF to get timings (see: https://github.com/admattingly/Macho/ ) but you can comment this out if you wish. Hopefully this logic is self-explanatory:

identification division.
program-id. wrangle.
environment division.
data division.
working-storage section.
01 cca-return-code pic 9(9) comp-5.
01 cca-reason-code pic 9(9) comp-5.
01 cca-exit-data-length pic 9(9) comp-5.
01 cca-exit-data pic x.
01 cca-rule-array-count pic 9(9) comp-5.
01 cca-rule-array.
05 cca-rule pic x(8) occurs 8.
01 rng-key-identifier-length pic 9(9) comp-5.
01 rng-key-identifier pic x(64).
01 rng-random-number-length pic 9(9) comp-5.
01 rng-random-number pic x(4096).
01 rng-function pic x(8) value 'CSNBRNGL'.
*
01 [...]
item.author: Andrew Mattingly <andrew@MATTINGLY.COM>

item.title: Re: Data Spaces in general
item.description:
I would not advise any new code use dataspaces. Use 64bit memory instead.

If you have existing dataspace code, the Extended Addressability manual is pretty good to use as a reference.

Rob Scott
Rocket Software

Sent from Outlook for Android<https://aka.ms/AAb9ysg>
item.author: Rob Scott <rscott@ROCKETSOFTWARE.COM>

item.title: Re: Mystified by FTP working for one user but not another
item.description: And sometimes you can't teach a new dog old tricks. Way back in my innocent youth I discovered what I called "young fogies"; people in their teens or 20s who were already ossified. As someone who is attracted to the bleeding edge and settles for the leading edge, I found them frustrating.

item.description:
On Wed, 12 Mar 2025 13:59:38 -0500, Paul Gilmartin <PaulGBoulder@AOL.COM> wrote:

>With which command line interfaces are you conversant?

Not sure "the public" cares but FWIW almost none. Trying to think of what I do from a command line. Use Windows GUI all the time but almost never the command line. Have a couple of .BAT scripts hung off of desktop icons -- that's it. I have used the CLI on my wife's Mac to solve problems but not in a while. I know almost enough z UNIX to be almost dangerous. ls and cat. chown and chmod. cp. mv. [...]

--
Matt Hogstrom

- Leonard Bernstein

item.title: Re: Mystified by FTP working for one user but not another
item.description:
From my wayback machine.  Ftp can have problems with firewall ruled.  There are active and passive modes.  Look for net blocks.
We forced ftps, (not sftp) which was another set of problems.  

Yahoo Mail - Email Simplified

item.author: Len Rugen <rugenl@YAHOO.COM>

item.title: Re: Mystified by FTP working for one user but not another
item.description:
Charles,

I recommend that you go register at the Zxplore website (link below) and start taking the “challenges” there to work your way up to the introductions to Unix access via ssh to a z/OS system (challenge USS1 et. seq.). They were most helpful to me in learning my way around the “new way” (i.e., not 3270) to access the mainframe and I would hope would do the same for you. IMHO well worth your time and effort. And who knows, you may find that you like it . . . :) [...]
item.author: Farley, Peter <Peter.Farley@BROADRIDGE.COM>

item.title: Re: Mystified by FTP working for one user but not another
item.description:
On Wed, 12 Mar 2025 11:26:40 -0500, Charles Mills wrote:
> ...
>But your post triggered a related thought: "can the new user access z/OS legacy data sets with FTP?" So after dinner last night I went and checked. And the answer is ...
>
FTP, certainly. It was there before OMVS. sftp? Probably not directly,
but with ISV alternatives. Rocket? Dovetailed? [...]
item.author: Paul Gilmartin <PaulGBoulder@AOL.COM>

item.title: Re: Mystified by FTP working for one user but not another
item.description:
On Tue, 11 Mar 2025 19:56:02 -0500, Paul Gilmartin <PaulGBoulder@AOL.COM> wrote:

>To add a little more TCP/IP to the mix, can both users alike access z/OS UNIX files
>via ssh/sftp?

You know, that's a real good thought. Unfortunately, I have zero experience with ssh and sftp and so that would be a whole new can of worms to take on. [...]

item.author: Seymour J Metz <smetz3@GMU.EDU>

item.title: Re: [EXT] Re: Dataspaces
item.description: Whatever the communication mechanism you choose between creator of, and users of, the scope=common dataspace, the owning task can not terminate before the users are done using it or the users will abend when attempting to access the space. So yes.
item.author: Glen Garrison <glene@US.IBM.COM>

item.author: Joseph Reichman <reichmanjoe@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: Dataspaces
item.description:
From z/OS extended addressability guide.....

Relationship between the data space and its owner
Your program can create a data space, but it cannot own the data space. If the unit of work that
represents the program is a TCB, that TCB is the owner of the data space, unless the program assigns
ownership to another TCB. If the unit of work is an SRB, the program must assign ownership to a TCB.
Because of this assignment of ownership, the owner of the data space and the creator of the data space
are not always the same TCB.
The data space [...]
item.author: Glen Garrison <glene@US.IBM.COM>

item.title: Dataspaces
item.description:
I have a question. If a program creates a dataspace, and the program ends or abends. Does the dataspace go away or is it still there?

item.title: Re: IBM Z Day: April 8, 2025
item.description:
Having been through a few releases, I think you can count on breaks every
hour after what might be a longer kick off session.
Chances are they (the folks responsible for delivering material), are still
trying to build content while getting things to work and behave as
expected.
Hopefully before the event, and to your point, they will break out each
track into focused content allowing folks to join the items most important
to them. [...]
item.author: Bfishing <bfishing@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: IBM Z Day: April 8, 2025
item.description: I am guessing. Since it's about an 'unannounced' product, they don't want to give too much detail ahead of the official announcement. Hence a very high-level abstract for the 3 tracks 🙂
item.author: P H <parwez_hamid@HOTMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: IBM Z Day: April 8, 2025
item.description:
That's not an agenda, that's a track description. I'm back to "Has nobody at IBM ever gone to a conference or even a user group meeting?" I can't block off the whole day on the off-chance that something is interesting!

At least it's virtual. A few years ago some org was pushing hard for me to attend an in-person conference, and their idea of an agenda was "sessions <times>, breaks <times>". I told them I couldn't commit to a day based on knowing when they were going to feed me; that seemed to be a tricky concept. [...]
item.author: Phil Smith III <lists@AKPHS.COM>

item.title: Re: IBM Z Day: April 8, 2025
item.description:
I guess I'm just to used to seeing ics files over little circles for
calendar invites:
A closer look showed me the following (noting that I am sure these will not
work unless you are registered):
Google and Apple ones worked just fine.

*Mark Your Calendar!*

Make sure you save the date by adding the event to your calendar: [...]
item.author: Bfishing <bfishing@GMAIL.COM>

item.title: Re: IBM Z Day: April 8, 2025
item.description:
*April 8th, 2025 10am - 5pm ET *

*Unveiling the future of mainframe technologies with 3 content-rich
technical tracks:*

*🔹IBM zNext* – Experience cutting-edge enterprise computing with IBM
zNext, featuring up to 8x AI processors per core for unmatched scale,
performance, and security. Discover innovations behind the systems powering
70% of global transactions.

*🔹AI & Data* – Unlock the potential of AI+ with IBM Z. Drive growth while
securing data, scaling AI with minimal performance impact. Harness
mainframe data for predictive modeling and AI-driven insights across
industries. [...]
item.author: Bfishing <bfishing@GMAIL.COM>
